captions.text:
If you've got any old lighters laying around,
get them ready, because we're gonna use
them for some mini pyrotechnic entertainment.

For this project, i'm using these cheap butane
lighters I found at a dollar store. 3 for

a buck! I'll get those out of the package,
and then volunteer this green one for disassembly.

A pair of needle nose pliers is great for
removing the valve guard, and that will give

me access to the tensioner that tightens and
loosens the valve. By manipulating the valve

counterclockwise, and much further than it
was ever intended, I can turn this little

lighter into a mini flame-thrower. This is
because a significant amount of gas is being

released now, which is obvious because of
the 12" flame shooting out. That's a foot

long flame, but be careful because your lighter
might catch on fire, and then what are you

going to do? Alright, to make a flint bomb,
I'll use my pliers to carefully remove the

striker wheel from the two plastic tabs. There's
a spring loaded piece of flint behind the

wheel, so I'll make sure not to lose it when
it comes flying out. I just need the spring

and the piece of flint, and when I'm ready,
I can stretch one end of the spring to make

a gap large enough to insert the flint. Wrapping
the spring around a couple of times ensures

the flint is held in place, and it should
look something like this. Time to light it

up. For convenience, I'm using a candle flame
so that I have both hands free to energize

the flint. It takes about 25 seconds to see
any result, but I do see it starting to glow

orange. And when it starts glowing this brightly,
it's ready for action. Just throw it on a

hard surface, and wham-o, you've got a little
mini firework. I'm not happy about how that

scorched my patio though, so I'm using a concrete
tile as my new target. This time I'll try

using another lighter to heat this piece of
flint, and I'm trying to keep it in the orange

part of the flame because that's where it's
the hottest. When it's glowing bright orange,

i've got about 5 seconds to throw it and get
the shower of sparks i'm looking for. Waiting

any longer than that could make it self destruct
before getting it out of your hands. And this

premature sparkulation results in another
scorch mark on my patio. I tried this at night,
and got some very impressive results.
I did some tests on the street, and

that made for a cool looking firework effect.
The sparks burn hot and look awesome, and

it's amazing to see how much light these flash
off. All my flint is used up now, but I still

have these lighter bodies packed full of liquid
butane .. and I'm sure there's something I

can use them for? Hmm, somehow this feels
like it could be a really dangerous idea.

Luckily, it's just sprung a leak and turned
into a dual flamethrower, but if I smash another

one down beside it, I get more of the fire
show I was hoping for. I'm gonna stand

far away for this one, because when the flame
burns through the red casing, it demonstrates

an amazing flaming fireball. Well that was
impressive. As long as you have enough lighters,

you can make a mini firework show that will
look like this. .. Or this, and this. How

about this, this and that. It only cost me
33¢ to do this flame, flash and boom. Well

that was a fun project but very dangerous
as well, so use extreme caution if you decide

to try this for yourself, or someone could
get hurt.
That's it for now. If you liked this project, perhaps you'll like some of my others.
Check them out, at thekingofrandom.com

comments.author: Mr Chicken

comments.text:
Don't want to read the whole thing? Read this: Blue flame is not always 
hotter than orange flame. The color of a flame depends on chemical 
reactions in the flame, not the temperature of a flame.
*_________________________*

It is misleading to make the general statement that "blue is *hotter* than 
yellow or orange" 

The different colors in a flame are a result of *different physical and 
chemical processes* within the flame, not strictly because of differences 
in temperature. (most web materials get this wrong....) 

If you read the fine print in a good physics book, you will find that a 
blue color corresponds to a temperature of about 20,000 degrees and 
upwards. This is far hotter than any known flame, and the only places you 
are likely to find these kind of temperatures is in electric arcs, 
lightning bolts, and very hot stars. Most flames are on the order of 1,500 
- 4,000 degrees, the hottest being an oxygen+acetylene welding flame, which 
is around 5,000 degrees, about that of a lightbulb. Not hot enough by far 
to produce a blue color.... 

So where does the blue color come from? 

The blue color is caused by "chemiluminescence," this is light which is 
produced *directly* from the chemical reactions of combustion, not 
indirectly as a result of heat (e.g. a red hot stove, or light bulb 
filament...) 

So where does the yellow color come from? Why are some flames white-yellow, 
and some flames completely blue? 

If some region of a flame does not have enough oxygen to burn completely, 
it will begin to form tiny soot particles. These soot particles are far 
more dense than the surrounding gas, so they glow a nice bright yellow 
color. As they reach the top of the flame, in-rushing air brings enough 
oxygen to burn up the soot particles completely. 

A reddish or orange flame usually means it contains excess soot or 
impurities; such flames will usually produce a lot of smoke. in particular, 
a yellowish orange comes from excess sodium. 

A flame that has enough oxygen, or a correct ratio of fuel to air, won't 
produce any soot at all, thus eliminating the bright yellow color. 
Incidentally, such flames usually burn more efficiently than those that are 
oxygen starved, hence the misleading assumption that "blue is hotter" 
Flames that don't contain carbon, such as those of burning hydrogen, 
ammonia, or sulfur, are usually bluish or colorless..... 

Probably way more than you wanted to know about fire.... 

---SPACEFACE *105*

Source(s):

o)http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemiluminescence
o)http://www.webexhibits.org/causesofcolor/3B.html
Note that blue flames are usually at the bottom of a flame, and orange near 
the top.

comments.text:
I'm not being a hater, I like this channel, but lighter pyrotechnics is a 
very bad idea. I know this as I have suffered the consequences myself. Me 
and a couple of friends were having a barbecue just below a small cliff, 
all was well and good until some teenagers dropped a lighter off the edge 
of the cliff into our barbecue. just as you would expect, it exploded. I 
got badly burnt on my lips and had my eyebrows and hair scorched off. My 
eyelashes got melted onto my eyes which was quite painful. Luckily me and 
my friends all got away with minor injuries but we all feel that it could 
have been a lot worse. Just be careful.﻿

comments.text:

tl;dr
The Illuminati is a name given to several groups, both real and fictitious. 
The society's goals were to oppose superstition, obscurantism, religious 
influence over public life and abuses of state power. They are often 
alleged to conspire to control world affairs, by masterminding events and 
planting agents in government and corporations, in order to gain political 
power and influence and to establish a New World Order. Central to some of 
the most widely known and elaborate conspiracy theories, the Illuminati 
have been depicted as lurking in the shadows and pulling the strings and 
levers of power in dozens of novels, movies, television shows, comics, 
video games and music videos.
comments.author: Jorge Bananas

comments.text: Too long didn't read.
comments.author: Ranger McFriendly

comments.text:
+life saver
The Illuminati (plural of Latin illuminatus, "enlightened") is a name given 
to several groups, both real and fictitious. Historically, the name refers 
to the Bavarian Illuminati, an Enlightenment-era secret society founded on 
May 1, 1776. The society's goals were to oppose superstition, obscurantism, 
religious influence over public life and abuses of state power. "The order 
of the day," they wrote in their general statutes, "is to put an end to the 
machinations of the purveyors of injustice, to control them without 
dominating them."[1] The Illuminati—along with Freemasonry and other secret 
societies—were outlawed through Edict, by the Bavarian ruler, Charles 
Theodore, with the encouragement of the Roman Catholic Church, in 1784, 
1785, 1787 and 1790.[2] In the several years following, the group was 
vilified by conservative and religious critics who claimed that they 
continued underground and were responsible for the French Revolution.
In subsequent use, "Illuminati" refers to various organisations which claim 
or are purported to have links to the original Bavarian Illuminati or 
similar secret societies, though these links are unsubstantiated. They are 
often alleged to conspire to control world affairs, by masterminding events 
and planting agents in government and corporations, in order to gain 
political power and influence and to establish a New World Order. Central 
to some of the most widely known and elaborate conspiracy theories, the 
Illuminati have been depicted as lurking in the shadows and pulling the 
strings and levers of power in dozens of novels, movies, television shows, 
comics, video games and music videos.

comments.author: Jaume Genaro

comments.text:
Another cool trick is to grind the flint with the striker wheel without 
causing a spark... after a minute if you flip the lighter upside down and 
tap it on a hard surface some flint dust will fall out... now turn your 
stove (coil top) on high, wait for it to get red-hot, and drop some dust on 
it to see a pretty rain of sparks :)  You can also coat a cigarette in the 
flint dust to make a cool sparkler﻿

i have done it and really man it was awesome i had some bunkers at the 
beach and when we went in and did the star trick it really lighted

the ligters ran out of fuel when we were in the middle and we went lost for 
about half an hour :P but the trick was pretty awesome to do :D ﻿
